entry.title: Tornado Warning issued April 1 at 10:31PM CDT until April 1 at 11:00PM CDT by NWS Springfield MO
entry.summary:
At 1031 PM CDT, a confirmed tornado was located near Willard, or 8 miles north of Republic, moving east at 50 mph.
HAZARD...Damaging tornado and tennis ball size hail.
SOURCE...Law enforcement confirmed tornado.
IMPACT...Flying debris will be dangerous to those caught without shelter. Mobile homes will be damaged or destroyed. Damage to roofs, windows, and vehicles will occur. Tree damage is likely.
Locations impacted include... Springfield, Republic, Battlefield, Willard, Brookline, Glidewell, and Bois D'arc.
This includes Interstate 44 between mile markers 59 and 68, and between mile markers 70 and 81.

entry.title: Flood Watch issued April 1 at 8:59PM MDT until April 7 at 3:00AM MDT by NWS Great Falls MT
entry.summary:
...The Flood Watch is extended for the following rivers in Montana...
Battle Creek near Chinook affecting Northern Blaine County zone.
.Warm temperatures may melt snowpack and increase river flows.
For the Battle Creek...including Chinook...flooding is possible.
* WHAT...Flooding is possible.
* WHERE...Battle Creek near Chinook.
* WHEN...From Friday morning to early Sunday morning.
* IMPACTS...At 12.0 feet, flooding usually is occurring over northern/central Blaine County along Battle Creek. Runoff from Cypress Hills in southern Canada could be the source of the water. Empty grain bins could be washed away.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:30 PM MDT Monday the stage was 2.1 feet. - Forecast...Flood stage may be reached late Friday morning, based on the latest forecast information. - Flood stage is 10.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Winter Storm Watch issued April 1 at 10:49PM EDT until April 4 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Gray ME
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy snow and sleet. Total snow accumulations greater than 8 inches and sleet accumulations up to one quarter of an inch possible. Winds could gust as high as 50 mph.
* WHERE...Coastal Waldo, Interior Waldo, Knox, Southern Somerset, and Central Somerset Counties.
* WHEN...From Wednesday evening through Thursday evening.
* IMPACTS...Periods of moderate and heavy snow will combine with gusty winds and low visibility to create dangerous driving conditions. Delay travel; use extreme caution if travel is necessary. The combination of strong, gusty winds and heavy, wet snow on tree limbs may cause tree damage resulting in downed power lines and power outages. The hazardous conditions could impact the Wednesday morning commute, and will likely impact the Wednesday evening and Thursday morning commutes.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...This is a expected to be a long-duration, multi-faceted event. While precipitation starts early Wednesday, intensity will increase Wednesday night into Thursday when some of the heaviest rates may fall accompanied by strong, gusty winds. Be prepared for a prolonged duration of impact.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Central Somerset; Southern Somerset; Interior Waldo; Knox; Coastal Waldo

cap:parameter.value: WINTER STORM WATCH REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM WEDNESDAY EVENING THROUGH THURSDAY EVENING

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued April 1 at 9:24PM CDT by NWS Chicago IL
entry.summary:
ESFLOT
Rainfall over the past 48 hours plus additional rain tonight into Tuesday could result in minor flooding on portions of the Kishwaukee, Des Plaines, Iroquois, Mazon, and Vermilion Rivers this week.
This outlook means that elevated water levels and impacts are possible, but not yet certain. Persons should closely monitor forecasts including the possibility of flood watches, warnings, and advisories.
Additional statements, including potential watches or warnings, will be issued Tuesday morning.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 1 at 8:22PM MDT by NWS Albuquerque NM
entry.summary: A cold front moving southwest into central New Mexico late this evening will create a period of light to moderate snow through early Tuesday morning. Travel conditions will deteriorate from northeast to southwest overnight with a period of snow and low visibility along I-25 from Las Vegas to Santa Fe and La Bajada, I-40 between Clines Corners, Edgewood, and Tijeras Canyon, U.S. 285 from Santa Fe to Espanola, and State Road 68 from Espanola to Taos. Snowfall amounts up to 2 inches are possible, especially above 6,500 feet. Slick travel conditions may linger over parts of the area for the Tuesday morning commute. Please allow extra time to reach your destination, slow down, and increase your traveling distance between vehicles.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Glorieta Mesa Including Glorieta Pass; Upper Rio Grande Valley; Espanola Valley; Santa Fe Metro Area; Sandia/Manzano Mountains Including Edgewood; Estancia Valley; Central Highlands

cap:parameter.value: A BURST OF SNOW WILL IMPACT PARTS OF CENTRAL NM TONIGHT

entry.title: Rip Current Statement issued April 1 at 8:54PM AST until April 2 at 6:00AM AST by NWS San Juan PR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Life-threatening rip currents due to breaking waves between 7-9 feet.
* WHERE...Beaches along the western coastline of Puerto Rico, between Rincon and Aguada. For the high surf, the most vulnerable areas include Barrio Espinal in Aguada.
* WHEN...Until 6AM AST Tuesday Morning.
* IMPACTS...Rip currents that can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water where it becomes difficult to return to safety. High waves that can wash over jetties and sweep people and pets onto jagged rocks.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Rip currents can occur anywhere you have breaking waves, like sandy beaches on the open ocean, but can also occur where there are solid structures,like jetties and piers or even rocks jutting out into the ocean.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 1 at 4:37PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
A strong storm moving north into the Chukchi Sea on Wednesday will bring water levels up 2 to 3 feet along the coast from the starting Wednesday night. This will cause water to move on top of the ice near the coast in some areas. This could cause trails that cross ice near the coast to become inundated. This event will be similar what happened March 20, 2024.
Winter Storm Warnings, Watches and Advisories have been issued for many of these areas and are available on the Internet at weather.gov/afg.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Kivalina and Red Dog Dock; Lower Kobuk Valley; Baldwin Peninsula; Northern Seward Peninsula; Shishmaref

cap:parameter.value: Strong Storm Causing Water To Move Onto Near Shore Ice Wednesday Night

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 1 at 4:37PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:

This will cause water to move on top of the ice near the coast in some areas. This could cause trails that cross ice near the coast to become inundated. Ice could push onto the beach along south facing coast lines. This event will be similar what happened March 20, 2024.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 1 at 3:34PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
A strong cold front will bring snow squalls, blowing snow, and reduced visibility along with much colder temperatures to the Interior from Fairbanks and the Tanana Valley south to the Alaska Range tonight and Tuesday.
1 to 3 inches of snow is expected from Fairbanks south to the Alaska Range Monday night into Tuesday. Northwest winds gusting over 30 mph will cause low visibility in blowing snow, and snow drifts will form. Temperatures will fall into the single digits tonight and then below zero Tuesday night. Northwest winds and blowing snow will reach Fairbanks, Nenana and Denali this evening and continue into Tuesday morning. The northwest winds and blowing snow will reach Delta Junction, Tok and the Eastern Alaska Range later tonight and early Tuesday morning and continue through the day Tuesday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Upper Tanana Valley; Delta Junction; Upper Chena River Valley; Tanana Flats; Eielson AFB and Salcha; Goldstream Valley and Nenana Hills; Chatanika River Valley; Two Rivers; Fairbanks Metro Area; Nenana; Northern Denali Borough; Southern Denali Borough; Eastern Alaska Range North of Trims Camp; Eastern Alaska Range South of Trims Camp

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 1 at 3:50PM CDT by NWS Des Moines IA
entry.summary:
Patchy dense fog is developing over far southern Iowa as a strong storm and warm front is helping to focus moisture over the region. Visibility has dropped to a quarter mile to 1/2 mile at a few locations and the fog is expected to expand into the evening hours. Visibility will be around a quarter mile at times this evening.
If traveling over or into southern Iowa this evening, be on the lookout for rapidly changing visibility and use caution when lower visibility is encountered. Use low beam headlights and allow for extra time to reach your destination safely. The fog will persist until mid evening west of Interstate 35 and nearly until midnight east of Interstate 35.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Cass; Adair; Madison; Warren; Adams; Union; Clarke; Lucas; Monroe; Wapello; Taylor; Ringgold; Decatur; Wayne; Appanoose; Davis

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued April 1 at 11:31AM CDT by NWS Chicago IL
entry.summary:
ESFLOT
Isolated flooding of ditches, creeks, and poor drainage areas likely across northeastern Illinois and northwestern Indiana, generally near and south of I-80. Flash flooding of creeks, streams, roadways, and poor drainage areas possible along and south of US-24. Significant river rises and minor river flooding possible along the Iroquois, Kankakee, and Illinois rivers.
A swath of heavy rainfall occurred along the I-80 corridor overnight, with rainfall accumulations up to 2.5 inches. Elsewhere in northern Illinois and northwestern Indiana, rainfall accumulations up to 0.5 inches were widespread. Soil moisture is at least slightly elevated across the area, with near saturated soil moisture conditions likely extending from near I-80 southward to near US-24. Showers and thunderstorms are expected to develop later today, with multiple rounds of rainfall moving through northern and central Illinois and northwestern Indiana occurring through tomorrow night. Storm movement tomorrow favors the possibility of multiple thunderstorms moving over the same general areas, which increases the chance of heavy rainfall accumulations. Multiple swaths of rainfall of 1-2 inches are possible, with isolated accumulations up to 3 inches, especially south of US-24.
This outlook means that elevated water levels and potential impacts are possible, but not yet certain. Persons should closely monitor forecasts including the possibility of flood watches, warnings, and advisories.
No additional Hydrologic Outlooks are expected for this event, but other flood related products may be issued and/or updated over the next few days as the threat evolves.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Ford, IL; Grundy, IL; Iroquois, IL; Kankakee, IL; Kendall, IL; La Salle, IL; Livingston, IL; Will, IL; Benton, IN; Jasper, IN; Lake, IN; Newton, IN; Porter, IN

entry.title: Rip Current Statement issued April 1 at 4:11AM CDT until April 2 at 1:00AM CDT by NWS Brownsville TX
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Dangerous south to north longshore currents with embedded rip currents expected.
* WHERE...Kenedy Island, Willacy Island and Cameron Island Counties.
* WHEN...Through late tonight.
* IMPACTS...Longshore currents and embedded rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The combination of southerly swell direction and building surf waves to 5 feet will push swimmers rapidly up the shoreline from south to north, especially at beaches of Cameron and Willacy County. A combination of longshore and rip currents are likely along Padre Island National Seashore in Kenedy County.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Kenedy Island; Willacy Island; Cameron Island
